DOCNAME: MIRCESKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
JUDGES: Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the Court by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
On DATE the applicant applied to ORG seeking dissolution of his marriage to PERSON due to marital problems .

On DATE PERSON gave birth to a daughter . That fact was brought to the applicant 's attention on DATE . At the meeting of CARDINAL DATE scheduled before ORG for reconciliation of the spouses , the applicant denied that the child was his . He claimed to have been separated from his wife since she left the house ( DATE ) and not to have been intimate for DATE . He confirmed that statement at the next meeting dated DATE . In the meantime , the applicant was recorded in the birth register as the child 's father . In his submissions of DATE , the applicant reiterated his doubts that he was the child 's biological father . In support , he stated that he had not been intimate with PERSON for DATE before the child was born .

On DATE ORG Instance accepted the applicant 's action and declared the marriage dissolved . It also ordered the applicant to pay PERCENT of his DATE salary as child maintenance . The court addressed the applicant 's denial of being the child 's biological father and confirmed that he had not still brought an action contesting the paternity , but that he had applied to ORG requesting a new time - limit to do so . It concluded accordingly that money paid in child maintenance might be recovered by the applicant if he successfully challenged his paternity in separate proceedings , if any .
On DATE ORG upheld that decision .
On DATE the public prosecutor informed the applicant that there were no grounds for lodging with ORG a request for the protection of legality .

On DATE the applicant requested , under section CARDINAL of LAW ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” , below ) , ORG to determine a new time - limit to disavow the paternity of the child . He reiterated his earlier observations made in the divorce proceedings and added that on DATE he had undergone CARDINAL sperm tests , which indicated that it was of poor quality . He further stated that that evidence had not existed within the time - limit set forth in CARDINAL LAW ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” , below ) . That request was communicated to PERSON for comments .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's request as having been based on the sperm tests only . It stated that no diagnosis had been provided that would attest the applicant 's infertility . It therefore concluded that there was no indication that the applicant was not the child 's father .

On DATE the applicant made a fresh request to ORG . He referred to the reconciliation proceedings before ORG in which he had contested his paternity . In addition to the earlier sperm tests , the applicant provided CARDINAL fresh sperm tests made DATE and DATE and CARDINAL analyses . The diagnosis indicated in the medical reports of CARDINAL and DATE issued by CARDINAL different medical institutions was “ asthenozoospermia ” and “ sterilitas ” . In vitro fertilisation was suggested to the applicant . PERSON was invited to present her arguments in reply .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's request , finding that it was based on the same evidence as his earlier request . It ruled that the medical reports and diagnosis did not sufficiently support the applicant 's request . The applicant stated that he was served with this decision on DATE .

According to section CARDINAL of LAW ( “ the LAW ” , consolidated version of CARDINAL DATE ) a husband is regarded as the father of a child born to his wife during wedlock or within DATE of a divorce .

Under section QUANTITY , the husband can contest the paternity of a child born to his wife during wedlock or within DATE of a divorce . In this connection , an action can be submitted within DATE when the husband learned of the child 's birth .

Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW provides that the husband can request ORG to specify a new time - limit for disclaiming of the paternity if new facts or evidence are discovered after the expiration of the time - limit specified in section CARDINAL LAW which cast doubts that he is the father of a child born to his wife .
